div.p: That's a great idea, Avinash—especially since you're already working with the MERN stack for your social network project. React.js is one of the most in-demand front-end libraries and can really level up your UI development skills.
Here’s why learning React is worth it:

li.p: Component-based architecture: Makes your code reusable and easier to manage.
Large community: Tons of libraries, tools, and help available.
Career value: Most startups and big companies use it—great for internships and jobs.
Seamless with Node.js: Since you're using the MERN stack, React fits perfectly on the front end.

div.p: Would you like a beginner-friendly roadmap or some curated resources to get started?

div.p: Great question, Avinash!
Vite is a modern front-end build tool that’s often used with React to speed up development and simplify setup. It's a powerful alternative to older tools like Create React App (CRA).
div.h3: What Vite does in a React project:

li.p: Lightning-fast dev server: Vite uses native ES modules and starts almost instantly, even in large projects.
Hot Module Replacement (HMR): Updates your app instantly in the browser as you save code—faster and smoother than CRA.
Modern build process: Uses Rollup under the hood for production builds—optimized and efficient.
Zero-config setup: You can scaffold a React project with just one command and start coding immediately.
Built-in TypeScript, JSX, CSS modules, and more: No need for extra config.

div.p: Vite makes React development faster, simpler, and more enjoyable—especially for modern projects.
Would you like help setting up a Vite + React project on your system?

div.p: You're seeing this error because PowerShell's execution policy is preventing scripts like npm.ps1 from running. This is a common security feature in Windows.
div.h3: ✅ Quick Fix: Change PowerShell Execution Policy
div.p: To allow Node.js/npm commands to work properly, you need to temporarily allow script execution. Follow these steps:

li.p: Open PowerShell as Administrator:
Search for "PowerShell"
Right-click > Run as Administrator
Run this command to change the execution policy for the current session only (safe method):

div.p: To permanently fix the "running scripts is disabled" error in PowerShell for npm and other development tools, you need to change the execution policy globally. Here's how to do it safely and permanently:

li.p: Press Start, type PowerShell
Right-click > Run as Administrator

hr.h4: 2. Run this command to change the policy for your user:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-md border-[0.5px] border-token-border-medium relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary

flex items-center gap-1 px-4 py-1 select-none

li.p: Scripts you write yourself can run.
Scripts downloaded from the internet must be signed by a trusted publisher.
Type Y and press Enter.

div.p: Great question, Avinash!
div.h3: 🔍 What are dependencies in a React (or any Node.js) project?
div.p: Dependencies are the external packages or libraries your project needs to run properly. They're listed in your project's package.json file under "dependencies" or "devDependencies".

hr.h3: 💡 Example in a React + Vite project:
hr.p: When you run:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-md border-[0.5px] border-token-border-medium relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary dark:bg-token-main-surface-secondary select-none rounded-t-[5px]
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary text-token-text-secondary dark:bg-token-main-surface-secondary flex items-center rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs

button.class: flex gap-1 items-center select-none px-4 py-1
flex items-center gap-1 px-4 py-1 select-none

div.class: overflow-y-auto p-4

hr.p: It installs things like:

li.p: React → for building the UI
React-DOM → for rendering React to the web
Vite → for bundling and running your dev server

hr.p: These are stored in the node_modules/ folder, and their versions are tracked in package-lock.json.

hr.h3: 📁 In package.json, you’ll see something like:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-md border-[0.5px] border-token-border-medium relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary dark:bg-token-main-surface-secondary select-none rounded-t-[5px]
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary text-token-text-secondary dark:bg-token-main-surface-secondary flex items-center rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs

button.class: flex gap-1 items-center select-none px-4 py-1
flex items-center gap-1 px-4 py-1 select-none

div.class: overflow-y-auto p-4

li.p: dependencies: Needed when the app runs.
devDependencies: Only needed during development (e.g., Vite, testing tools).

hr.p: In simple terms:

blockquote.p: Dependencies = the tools and libraries your project depends on to work.

hr.p: Would you like help understanding package.json or adding your own components next?

div.p: Absolutely, Avinash—here’s a super simple explanation:

hr.p: Think of dependencies like ingredients you need to cook a dish.
When you're building a React app, you need some tools (ingredients) like:

li.p: React (to build the UI)
React DOM (to show it in the browser)
Vite (to run and build your app)

hr.p: These tools are called dependencies because your app depends on them to work.

hr.h3: ✅ Why do we run npm install?
hr.p: When you run:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-md border-[0.5px] border-token-border-medium relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary dark:bg-token-main-surface-secondary select-none rounded-t-[5px]
sticky top-9
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2
bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary text-token-text-secondary dark:bg-token-main-surface-secondary flex items-center rounded-sm px-2 font-sans text-xs

button.class: flex gap-1 items-center select-none px-4 py-1
flex items-center gap-1 px-4 py-1 select-none

div.class: overflow-y-auto p-4

hr.p: It’s like going to the grocery store to grab all the ingredients listed in your recipe (package.json) and put them in your kitchen (node_modules folder).

li.p: Dependencies = tools your app needs
npm install = download those tools
package.json = list of tools your app needs

hr.p: Want to see how you can create your first React component now?

div.p: Great question, Avinash!

hr.h3: 🧩 What is a Card component in React?
hr.p: A Card component is a UI block used to display content in a clean, structured box. It usually includes elements like:

li.p: A title
An image or icon
Some text (like a description)
Maybe a button or link

hr.h3: 🧠 Think of it like a digital business card:
hr.p: It groups related information into a small, neat box that’s easy to read.

div.p: Yes, Avinash—if you want VS Code to automatically detect and suggest CSS class names (especially Tailwind CSS) as you type, you should install a helpful extension.

hr.h3: ✅ If you’re using Tailwind CSS, do this:

li.p: Open VS Code
Go to the Extensions tab (or press Ctrl+Shift+X)

Search for:
👉 "Tailwind CSS IntelliSense"
Click Install

hr.p:
🔗 Or click this link if you're in VS Code’s browser:
Tailwind CSS IntelliSense — VS Marketplace

li.p: Autocompletes Tailwind classes like bg-blue-500, p-4, rounded-lg, etc.
Shows colors, spacing, and hover effects as you type
Gives warnings if you use invalid class names

hr.p:
If you're writing normal .css files, VS Code will usually detect class names automatically.
But for better CSS workflow, also install:

p.strong: IntelliSense for CSS class names in HTML

li.p: PostCSS Language Support (if using modern tools)

div.p: Great question, Avinash!

hr.p: In simple terms:

p.strong: Hooks are special functions in React that let you "hook into" features like state, lifecycle, and more — without writing a class.

hr.p: Before hooks, you had to use class components to manage state or lifecycle methods. With hooks, you can do the same (and more) in function components.

div.class: _tableWrapper_16hzy_14 group flex w-fit flex-col-reverse

tr.td: Lets you add state to function components
Runs side effects (like fetching data or setting timers)
Keeps a reference to DOM or a value without re-rendering
Shares values across components without props

hr.p: Every time the button is clicked, count updates and the component re-renders with the new value.

blockquote.p: Hooks make functional components powerful. They let you manage data, effects, and interactions — without using classes.

div.p: Nice work, Avinash! 🙌 You're already using useState correctly to toggle the "Like" state inside each card. That’s a great start to understanding React Hooks!

hr.h3: 🧠 Here's what's happening in your code:

li.p: You're using:

div.class: contain-inline-size rounded-md border-[0.5px] border-token-border-medium relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary
flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary dark:bg-token-main-surface-secondary select-none rounded-t-[5px]

li.p: hasLiked holds the current like status (true/false).
setHasLiked() updates it when the button is clicked.
The button shows "Like" or "Liked" depending on the state.
When clicked, it toggles between the two using:

div.p: Nice update, Avinash! You’re combining useState and useEffect like a pro. Here's a quick breakdown of what you’ve done — plus a small improvement suggestion.

li.p: hasLiked: Toggles between like/unlike and logs to console when liked.
count: Increments every time you click the entire card.

useEffect: Runs only when hasLiked changes and logs:
"Star wars has been liked" or "Avatar has been liked".

hr.h3: ⚠ Small Issue: Button Click also triggers Card Click
hr.p: Since both the card and the button are clickable:

li.p: Clicking the button also triggers the card's onClick, increasing the count.

hr.h3: ✅ 🔧 Fix: Prevent click event from bubbling up
hr.p: Use e.stopPropagation() inside the button:

div.p: Great question, Avinash!

hr.h3: ✅ What is Conditional Rendering in React?

blockquote.p: Conditional rendering means showing or hiding parts of your UI based on some condition (like a boolean or variable value).

hr.p:
It’s like saying:
“If this is true, show this. If not, show something else.”

div.p: Yes, there are several free hosting services that allow you to deploy your websites or web applications, including React apps, without any cost. Here are some of the most popular ones:

li.p: Perfect for static sites (like a React build).
Free hosting with your own domain or username.github.io domain.
Works great for personal projects or portfolios.
Push your code to a GitHub repository.
In your React app, run npm run build to create the production build.
Push the build folder to GitHub and enable GitHub Pages in the settings.

hr.p: 🔗 GitHub Pages Docs

li.p: Free hosting for both static and dynamic sites.
Offers features like automatic deployments and GitHub integration.
Fast and easy setup with seamless integration for React apps.
Connect your GitHub repository.
Push your React code to GitHub.
Vercel automatically deploys your app.

hr.p: 🔗 Vercel Docs

li.p: Very popular for frontend frameworks (React, Vue, Angular).
Free tier allows you to deploy static websites with continuous deployment from GitHub, GitLab, or Bitbucket.
Connect your GitHub repository.
Netlify automatically builds your React app and deploys it.

hr.p: 🔗 Netlify Docs

li.p: Ideal for static websites and single-page apps (SPA).
Offers a generous free tier (1GB storage, 10GB bandwidth).
Install Firebase CLI: npm install -g firebase-tools
Initialize Firebase in your project using firebase init.
Run firebase deploy to deploy your React app.

hr.p: 🔗 Firebase Hosting Docs

li.p: Similar to Vercel and Netlify, but also offers free hosting for static sites and backend applications.
Easy integration with GitHub repositories.
Connect your GitHub repo.
Render automatically deploys your React app.

hr.p: 🔗 Render Docs

li.p: Surge is a simple tool for publishing static websites.
Offers a free plan with unlimited publishing, simple setup, and CLI-based deployment.
Install Surge: npm install -g surge
Build your app with npm run build.
Deploy using surge ./build.

hr.p: 🔗 Surge Docs

hr.p: If you're working on a React app, Vercel, Netlify, and GitHub Pages are fantastic free hosting options that are simple to set up. Firebase Hosting is also a great choice if you want more flexibility.

hr.p: But if you accidentally deleted or moved vite.svg, this error will appear.
If you’re not using the Vite logo in your app:

li.p: Open your file (probably App.jsx or main.jsx)
Remove this line:

hr.p: If you want to keep using the Vite logo:

li.p:
Create a folder:
my-first-react-app/public/
Add the missing vite.svg file inside the public folder.

hr.p:
You can download the official Vite logo from here:
📎 https://vitejs.dev/logo.svg
Just save it as vite.svg in the public folder.

hr.h3: 💡 Tip: How public folder works in Vite
hr.p: Files inside /public are served as root-relative URLs. So /vite.svg means:

div.p: Avinash, this error is still showing because your React project is trying to load vite.svg, but that file is missing from the /public folder.
